conclusion: Analyzing the optical problem using principles of refraction and relationship between diffraction and wavelength.

Hemispherical glass brick with flat surface AB facing upward; two monochromatic light beams a and b incident perpendicularly on AB; beams enter at points equidistant from center point C; beams intersect at point P inside the glass.
Second figure shows angles of incidence (i₁, i₂) and angles of refraction (r₁, r₂).
Beams incident perpendicularly to flat surface AB travel straight into the glass without bending; refraction occurs at curved hemispherical surface.
Beams initially travel parallel to OO' axis; refract according to Snell's law at curved surface; paths after refraction must be different since they meet at point P.
Snell's law: n₁sin(i) = n₂sin(r), where n₁ is refractive index of glass, n₂ is refractive index of air, i is angle of incidence, r is angle of refraction.
Refractive index of a material depends on frequency of light, known as dispersion.
Higher frequency light (shorter wavelength) generally experiences a higher refractive index; lower frequency light (longer wavelength) generally experiences a lower refractive index.
Both beams reach point P despite different frequencies, indicating different amounts of refraction at curved surface; refractive indices within glass must be different.
Diffraction is bending of waves around obstacles, more pronounced with longer wavelengths or when aperture size is comparable to wavelength.
Beam a must have higher frequency (shorter wavelength); beam b must have lower frequency (longer wavelength) since higher frequency light bends more.
Since diffraction is more pronounced with longer wavelengths, beam b would be more likely to exhibit diffraction compared to beam a.
Conclusion: Light b is more likely to exhibit diffraction than light a; beam b has lower frequency (longer wavelength), leading to stronger diffraction effects.
